text:
Jarvis might be helpful. It's an AI tool that creates content. Some writers generally use it to help them structure outlines better. You can choose your topic and tone. You can work on outlines, intros, etc.

Might be worth a try in your case.

PS: Although it artificially creates content, you should use it as something that will help you create a draft instead of relying on it entirely.

text:
How do you go about monitoring ever-changing facts on your site?

 In fintech, mortgage rates might be  x one day and y the next, but a bunch of articles on your site state the x number -- what system do you have in place to monitor for these dynamically changing facts in all your content?

text:
Our content team is part of a multi-layered marketing team. The hierarchy is Marketing > Brand & Communications > Content. I lead the content team and report to our VP of Brand & Comms. That VP reports to our SVP of Marketing. The Brand & Comms team serves as an internal agency, basically. It includes my team (writers and one SEO specialist) plus people who focus on design, social media, events, and PR/comms. So we field requests from other teams (including other marketing functions like growth/demand and product marketing). But we also have our own brand initiatives.

We have three writers on the content team, and their work can sometimes be interchangeable. But for the most part, I've tried to give them ownership / specialities. So one focuses more on the core brand work (blog, podcast, larger brand campaign content); one focuses more on website/SEO and event collateral; and one focuses more on growth content like ads and customer and partner initiatives.

We have three writers on the content team, and their work can sometimes be interchangeable. But for the most part, I've tried to give them ownership / specialities. So one focuses more on the core brand work (blog, podcast, larger brand campaign content); one focuses more on website/SEO and event collateral; and one focuses more on growth content like ads and customer and partner initiatives.

text:
Hey <@U02UTRR1LFN>, I assume you mean for guest blogs, right?

I manage the guest blogging program for a few of my clients, and so typically, it looks more or less like this:

1. Judge the quality of their pitch / outreach email. Is their English, grammar, and spelling good? Is their pitch decent or does it sound like the other 100 sitting in your inbox? First impression is key, so if you’re already underwhelmed, just toss their message in the trash (this first step alone will weed out at least half or more of the pitches you receive)
2. If you like their message and pitch, send them a link to your blog’s guidelines and ask them to send you past writing samples (to further judge the quality of their writing, particularly with guest posts — some will be surprisingly bad, so you can again toss those emails) *and* 3-4 relevant topic ideas that meet your guidelines. This step is crucial and will also weed out a good %, as many will send topics that manage to not meet your guidelines at all or even be relevant to your audience. From there, you will have an even smaller pile of pitches to actually sort through. 
3. Once you’ve confirmed a topic with them, the rest is pretty straight forward. Personally, I always ask the writer to send an outline first, to assure we’re aligned and on the same page, and again, to further judge the quality to be expected. If the outline is garbage, here is another final option to weeding out the bad quality submissions _before_ you even get to a first draft. Leave any comments or suggestions as needed on the outline.
4. Once you receive a first draft, do a quick review. Does it require many edits that could have easily been solved with Grammarly? Don’t bother making any edits or reading further until they run through Grammarly or a similar tool, first, and then have them send the draft back. Normally, I leave suggested edits and ask them to revise whatever is needed. If it looks like it is going to take a lot of edits or >1 hour of time to review/edit, generally, these get tossed as it isn’t worth the resources or bandwidth, depending on the blog’s priorities and how much they really value or want guest blog content.
5. Follow usual process for uploading to WP, scheduling, + publishing.
I’ve had some clients who didn’t want to actively focus on a guest blog program, but, they wanted to use guest posts to somewhat maintain their blog and keep it “alive” while they focused on other things and invested less in content themselves…

In these instances, would adjust the steps above a tad, and assign topics ourselves to the guest writers, and also provide the outline in these instances ourselves, as most of the time, we wanted to optimize it well for seo so that the content could bring in some traffic, and not just be another guest blog sitting on the website. Whenever the guest blog program was used for this purpose, it also further cut back on the successful pitches/submissions, as you’ll find less guest bloggers willing to go through the “hoops”, so to speak, but those who will, generally provide great content.

The main thing to look for, in my opinion, is if the writer follows the most basic instructions. If they don’t even bother to pitch topics that are relevant to your blog + audience, or that match your guidelines, then that’s enough of a red flag not to move forward. You especially want to try and weed out the ones who are just looking to submit posts that look like a link farm, and really have no interest in providing valuable/quality content.

I think that’s it in a nutshell, happy to help in any other way if there’s any follow up questions to this, or share examples of guest blog guidelines, etc :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Question for the group! What are some blog platform features that have helped you get more out of your content/audience? Thinking things like newsletter subscription pop-ups, gated content promoted in a page’s sidebar, etc. TIA!

elements.text: Question for the group! What are some blog platform features that have helped you get more out of your content/audience? Thinking things like newsletter subscription pop-ups, gated content promoted in a page’s sidebar, etc. TIA!

text:
OK that makes sense ... and I guess unless you're pulling those from dynamic systems that update automatically, my answer is the same... you'd want a content management system that would allow you to pull all instances of a particular 'fact' from one piece of content, so you'd change that in one place and it would be updated everywhere. Again, I'm not an expert so I'm probably dumbing this down.

That said, if anyone has a more manual way of doing this (like, lower budget!) I would be curious about the answer myself.

text: When I worked in fintech and rates often changed, we would be sure to date the material. Literally just adding fine print off to the side or the bottom that said the last date the info was verified to be accurate. Not as fancy as having a dynamic widget but if you're on a budget, it gets the jobs done and protects you a bit more

text: Hi Everyone! I'm evaluating a clients internal sales "WIN" slides/summaries and I'm curious if the community here has any advice for a more modern take on the content included, e.g. deal summary, customer challenge, solution, why we won, winning team, etc. What is considered "must include/best practice" criteria and is there any content fields that are considered outdated info to include at this point? Thanks in advance!

text: Hi folks, we're finally adding a copywriter on our marketing team, and there's a question about whether copywriter should report into a design org or the content org. Would love to hear thoughts from folks on this debate and where copywriting sits in your org.

elements.text: Hi folks, we're finally adding a copywriter on our marketing team, and there's a question about whether copywriter should report into a design org or the content org. Would love to hear thoughts from folks on this debate and where copywriting sits in your org.

text: I’m a freelance copywriter with 2 main clients. With both clients, I report directly to the head of marketing, and collaborate with other members of the team including in-house and outside designers. Director of content manages content writers, head of marketing manages me.

elements.text: I’m a freelance copywriter with 2 main clients. With both clients, I report directly to the head of marketing, and collaborate with other members of the team including in-house and outside designers. Director of content manages content writers, head of marketing manages me.

text: Hi everyone! I know content strategy is very subjective but is there a template one can use to get a generic direction?

elements.text: Hi everyone! I know content strategy is very subjective but is there a template one can use to get a generic direction?

text:
I would highly recommend content. 1) Content team will be able to speak the same language as the copywriter, understand creative process and provide editorial direction and feedback. 2) equally important is the consideration of that new copywriter's career path. sitting in the design org, they may not be exposed to the same opportunities and peers as in the content org. sitting in the content org, they will be able to learn new skills, branch out to broader content marketing or editorial teams

However, if a relationship with design is important, it should be clear from the beginning that there needs to be strong collaboration between the copywriter and design. Offer weekly 1/1s with peers or a cadence that will foster strong collaboration between both teams

elements.text:
I would highly recommend content. 1) Content team will be able to speak the same language as the copywriter, understand creative process and provide editorial direction and feedback. 2) equally important is the consideration of that new copywriter's career path. sitting in the design org, they may not be exposed to the same opportunities and peers as in the content org. sitting in the content org, they will be able to learn new skills, branch out to broader content marketing or editorial teams

However, if a relationship with design is important, it should be clear from the beginning that there needs to be strong collaboration between the copywriter and design. Offer weekly 1/1s with peers or a cadence that will foster strong collaboration between both teams

text: I have done both, and believe it comes down to the type of work the copywriter will do. If it's all content for pre-login touchpoints—campaigns, blog, ads, landing pages, etc—marketing is best. But if this writer would be doing in-product work like interface copy and product content strategy, they should report into design.

elements.text: I have done both, and believe it comes down to the type of work the copywriter will do. If it's all content for pre-login touchpoints—campaigns, blog, ads, landing pages, etc—marketing is best. But if this writer would be doing in-product work like interface copy and product content strategy, they should report into design.
